   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   54-yo man with hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal
   cancer s/p chemo-XRT & esophagectomy, recent left pleural effusion s/p
   thoracentesis and recent pericardial effusion with tamponade s/p
   pericardiocentesis [**2112-5-23**], who was admitted to [**Hospital1 2266**] with asymptomatic
   tachycardia and is now being transferred to CCU with recurrent
   pericardial effusion and early tamponade.
   .
   # Pericardial effusion with early tamponade- has kausumal sign and
   pulsus currently [**7-25**]. For etiology it is very possible this is a
   malignant effusion vs. infectious due to recent instrumentation.  Pt
   does have low grade fever 99 and WBC 14.9. Although cytology negative,
   but low sensitivity, and still likely malignant effusion.
   - pericardiocentesis today w/ pigtail
   - Thoracic will take to OR tomorrow for pericardial window
   - NPO p MN
   - post- pericardiocentesis Echo today
   - continue checking serial pulsus
   - if tamponade worsens for some reason first step would be to give IVF
   then try pressors
   # Pleural effusions
Thoracics will drain L pleural effusion tomorrow
   when doing pericardial window
   - continue to monitor resp status
   .
   # CORONARIES - No h/o CAD, normal stress 1/[**2111**].
   .
   # PUMP - TTEs all with EF >55%. Appears hypovolemic to euvolemic.
   - IVF hydration as above for early tamponade
   .
   # RHYTHM - Sinus tachycardia.
   - cont to monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Esophageal Ca - Pt s/p chemo-XRT and esophagectomy. Concern for
   malignant pleural and pericardial effusions.
   - further plans per primary oncology team, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5112**]
   - f/u thoracic surgery recs, appreciate involvement
   .
   # Hypertension - BP stable, off atenolol.
   - cont to hold atenolol
   .
   # Dyslipidemia - Previously treated with Lovastatin, but has been off
   this since diagnosis of esophageal Ca.
   - lipid panel pending
   .
   # ? Diabetes - If pt diabetic, currently diet-controlled.
   - Hgb A1c pending
   - FSBS QIDACHS, HISS to cover
   .
   # Anemia - Pt started on iron supplementation for Fe-deficient anemia
   on last hospitalization. Now with decrease in Hct from 32 to 26
   overnight, although was in similar range on prior hospitalization.
   - cont home iron supplements
   - Guaiac stools
   - checking daily Hcts
   .
   FEN: NPO for procedure, afterwards can start diabetic cardiac diet. IVF
   hydration. Replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: PIVs
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Morphine
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, Dulcolax
   FULL CODE
   DISPO: CCU for now
   HCP: [**Name (NI) 6511**] [**Name (NI) 6510**] (Father) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6512**]-cell and
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6513**]-work
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2112-5-29**] 02:21 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2112-5-29**] 02:28 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:
   ------ Protected Section ------
   I agreed with the comprehensive admission note as outlined by Dr.
   [**Last Name (STitle) 4633**] on [**2112-5-29**].   I concur with the documentation of the
   admission history.  The physical examination is consistent with my
   examination and the assessment and management describe our plans over
   the next 24 hours.  Mr. [**Known lastname 6510**] is a 54 year old man with
   esophageal carcinoma who developed a recurrent pericardial effusion
   with borderline tamponade physiologically by clinical examination and
   echocardiography.  He has shortness of breath.  We will plan with
   pericardiocentesis followed by a pericardial window to prevent
   recurrence.  The management plan was discussed with the patient.

   on:[**2112-5-29**] 13:57 ------<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal cancer, and recent left pleural effusion and pericardial effusion. He was admitted to the ICU with asymptomatic tachycardia and is now being transferred to the CCU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Tachycardia with a heart rate of 108 bpm
* Hypertension with a blood pressure of 118/83 mmHg
* Respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute
* SpO2 of 99%
* Mild-moderate discomfort
* Diaphoretic and ill-appearing

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count of 14.9 K/uL
* Hemoglobin of 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count of 154 K/uL
* Creatinine of 0.7 mg/dL
* Troponin-T of <0.01
* Glucose of 151 mg/dL

The patient has a pericardial effusion with early tamponade, which is likely malignant in origin. He has a low-grade fever and is at risk for further complications. The patient's pericardial effusion is being managed with pericardiocentesis and a pericardial window will be performed tomorrow.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Malignant pleural and pericardial effusions
* Recurrent pericardial tamponade
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Hypovolemic shock
* Infection
* Bleeding complications from pericardiocentesis and pericardial window

The patient's management plan includes:

* Pericardiocentesis with a pigtail catheter
* Pericardial window
* Thoracic drainage of left pleural effusion
* IVF hydration
* Monitoring of serial pulsus
* Continuous checking of respiratory status
* Further plans per primary oncology team

The patient's code status is full code, and he is being monitored in the CCU.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal cancer, and recent left pleural effusion and pericardial effusion with tamponade. He was admitted to the ICU with asymptomatic tachycardia and is being transferred to the CCU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate of 108 bpm, blood pressure of 118/83 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on nasal cannula. He is diaphoretic and ill-appearing, but oriented x3 with a normal mental status.

The patient has a pericardial effusion with early tamponade, which is likely malignant in origin given his recent instrumentation and cytology-negative results. He has a low-grade fever and a white blood cell count of 14.9 K/μL. The patient will undergo pericardiocentesis with a pigtail catheter today, followed by a pericardial window procedure tomorrow.

The patient also has a left pleural effusion, which will be drained during the pericardial window procedure tomorrow. He is at risk for respiratory compromise due to his respiratory status and will continue to be monitored.

The patient's cardiac function is normal, with an ejection fraction greater than 55% on transthoracic echocardiography. He has a sinus tachycardia and will continue to be monitored on telemetry.

The patient has a history of esophageal cancer, and his primary oncology team will provide further plans for his management. He has a history of hypertension, which is currently stable, and dyslipidemia, which is currently untreated. He may have diabetes, but this is pending further evaluation.

The patient has a history of anemia, which is being treated with iron supplementation. He will continue to receive iron supplements and will have his hemoglobin level checked daily.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Tamponade cardiomyopathy: The patient's pericardial effusion with early tamponade may lead to cardiac compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is at risk due to his pleural effusion and may lead to respiratory failure.
3. Infection: The patient's recent instrumentation and low-grade fever may indicate an underlying infection, which could worsen his condition.
4. Malignant effusion: The patient's malignant effusion may continue to expand and cause life-threatening complications.
5. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's hypovolemia may worsen and lead to hypovolemic shock if not properly managed.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's sinus tachycardia may worsen and lead to cardiac arrhythmias, which could be life-threatening.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen and lead to complications such as heart failure, if not properly managed.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and manage his symptoms and underlying conditions to prevent these potential complications from arising.

Summary:

The patient, a 54-year-old man, is being transferred to the Cardiac Care Unit (CCU) from the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade. He has a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal cancer, and recent left pleural effusion and pericardial effusion. The patient's condition is unstable, with a pericardial effusion causing early tamponade, and he requires urgent pericardiocentesis and pericardial window creation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pericardial tamponade: The patient's condition is at high risk for further tamponade due to the rapid re-accumulation of pericardial fluid. This may lead to cardiac compromise, including decreased cardiac output, hypotension, and even cardiac arrest.
2. Malignant effusions: The patient's effusions may be malignant, which could lead to further complications, including recurrence of effusions, and potentially, cardiac tamponade.
3. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's hypovolemic state may worsen due to fluid loss and inadequate fluid replacement, leading to decreased cardiac output, hypotension, and potentially, organ failure.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate due to pleural effusions, leading to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.
5. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state may increase the risk of infection, particularly in the pericardial and pleural spaces.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's sinus tachycardia may worsen due to hypovolemia, electrolyte imbalances, or cardiac ischemia, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation.
7. Renal failure: The patient's hypovolemic state and potential electrolyte imbalances may lead to acute kidney injury or renal failure.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's esophageal cancer and recent esophagectomy may lead to gastrointestinal complications, including obstruction, perforation, or bleeding.

These potential complications highlight the need for close monitoring and prompt intervention to address the patient's unstable condition and prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal cancer, and recent pericardial effusion with tamponade. He was admitted to the ICU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade. The patient has a low-grade fever, tachycardia, and decreased breath sounds at bases. He has a pericardial effusion with early tamponade, and the plan is for pericardiocentesis tomorrow morning followed by a pericardial window by thoracics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Malignant effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may be malignant, which could lead to further complications and worsening of his condition.
2. Infectious effusion: The patient's recent instrumentation may have introduced an infectious agent, leading to a pericardial effusion with potential complications.
3. Tamponade: The patient's early tamponade may worsen if not properly managed, leading to cardiac compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and decreased breath sounds at bases may indicate early signs of respiratory failure, which could worsen if not properly managed.
5. Anemia: The patient's decreased Hct overnight may indicate ongoing bleeding or hemolysis, which could worsen his anemia and require further management.
6. Hypovolemia: The patient's hypovolemic status may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further cardiac compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. DVT: The patient's risk of DVT may be increased due to his immobility and recent instrumentation, which could lead to potentially life-threatening complications.
8. VAP: The patient's risk of VAP may be increased due to his recent instrumentation and immobility, which could lead to potentially life-threatening complications.
9. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further cardiac compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
10. Dyslipidemia: The patient's dyslipidemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further cardiac complications and potentially life-threatening outcomes.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage potential complications.

Summary:

The patient, a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal cancer, and recent pericardial effusion with tamponade, was admitted to the ICU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade. The patient's condition is being managed with pericardiocentesis and pericardial window creation. He also has a history of pleural effusions, which will be drained in the morning.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate of 108 bpm, blood pressure of 118/83 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. His respiratory status is being monitored, and he is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula.

The patient's physical examination reveals a diaphoretic and ill-appearing man with mild-moderate discomfort, tachypnea, and decreased breath sounds at the bases. His cardiac examination shows a regular rhythm, distant heart sounds, and a pericardial rub. His abdominal examination is normal, and his extremities show no signs of edema or cyanosis.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 154 K/uL. His troponin-T level is <0.01 ng/mL, and his creatinine level is 0.7 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Recurrent pericardial effusion and tamponade: The patient's condition is at risk of worsening, and further interventions may be necessary to manage the effusion and tamponade.
2. Malignant pleural and pericardial effusions: The patient's esophageal cancer may be causing the effusions, and further treatment may be necessary to manage the cancer and prevent future effusions.
3. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's hypovolemic status may lead to shock, particularly if the pericardial effusion and tamponade are not adequately managed.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and decreased breath sounds at the bases may indicate respiratory failure, which may worsen if not managed promptly.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's sinus tachycardia may worsen if not managed, and cardiac arrhythmias may develop due to the pericardial effusion and tamponade.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed, particularly if the bleeding is not controlled.
7. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state may increase his risk of infection, particularly if the pericardial effusion and tamponade are not adequately managed.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and respiratory status closely.
2. Perform pericardiocentesis and pericardial window creation as planned.
3. Manage the patient's pain and discomfort with morphine and other analgesics.
4. Continue IVF hydration to manage the patient's hypovolemic status.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely for signs of cardiac arrhythmias or failure.
6. Manage the patient's anemia with iron supplements and other treatments as necessary.
7. Consider further treatment for the patient's esophageal cancer, including chemotherapy and radiation therapy.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 54-yo man with hypertension, dyslipidemia,
   locally-advanced esophageal cancer s/p chemo-XRT & esophagectomy,
   recent left pleural effusion s/p thoracentesis and recent pericardial
   effusion with tamponade s/p pericardiocentesis [**2112-5-23**], who was admitted
   to [**Hospital1 2266**] with asymptomatic tachycardia and is now being transferred to
   CCU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade.
   .
   # Pericardial effusion with early tamponade - Pt w/ tachycardia, pulsus
   of [**7-25**]. Etiology unclear, may be malignant especially given rapid rate
   of re-accumulation, although cytology has been negative. Also consider
   reactive to recent chemo/XRT. With new low-grade fever, elevated WBC
   and left-shift, and diaphoresis, concern also for infectious etiology,
   especially with recent pericardial procedure, although ECG without
   evidence of true pericarditis. Blood cx pending from ED. Transferred to
   CCU for closer monitoring.
   - NPO for pericardiocentesis in AM
   - will send pericardial fluid for analysis as well as microbiology and
   cytology
   - appreciate thoracic surgery recs, may need pericardial window given
   rapid re-accumulation
   - continue IVF hydration for volume expansion
   - close BP monitoring and monitoring of pulsus
   - consider broad-spectrum antibiotics for empiric coverage
   .
   # Pleural effusions - Enlarging on CXR compared to those present on
   recent discharge. Rapid re-accumulation of these also makes malignant
   effusions more likely, although cytology was again negative, as opposed
   to reactive to chemo/XRT.
   - continue to monitor resp status

   .

   - IVF hydration as above for early tamponade
   .

   - cont to monitor on telemetry
   .

   - further plans per primary oncology team, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5112**]
   - f/u thoracic surgery recs, appreciate involvement
   .
   # Hypertension - BP stable, off atenolol.
   - cont to hold atenolol
   .
   # Dyslipidemia - Previously treated with Lovastatin, but has been off
   this since diagnosis of esophageal Ca.
   - lipid panel pending
   .
   # ? Diabetes - If pt diabetic, currently diet-controlled.
   - Hgb A1c pending
   - FSBS QIDACHS, HISS to cover
   .
   # Anemia - Pt started on iron supplementation for Fe-deficient anemia
   on last hospitalization. Now with decrease in Hct from 32 to 26
   overnight, although was in similar range on prior hospitalization.
   - cont home iron supplements
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   FEN: NPO for procedure, afterwards can start diabetic cardiac diet. IVF
   hydration. Replete lytes PRN.

The patient's condition is complicated by the presence of pleural effusions, which are enlarging on CXR, and the patient's recent pericardial procedure. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 108 bpm, blood pressure of 118/83 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's physical examination is notable for diaphoresis, tachypnea, and decreased breath sounds at the bases.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pericardial tamponade: The patient's pericardial effusion is causing early tamponade, which can lead to cardiac arrest if not treated promptly.
2. Infectious etiology: The patient's new low-grade fever, elevated WBC, and left-shift, and diaphoresis raise concern for an infectious etiology, especially with recent pericardial procedure.
3. Malignant effusions: The patient's pleural and pericardial effusions may be malignant, which can lead to respiratory and cardiac complications.

5. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and decreased breath sounds at the bases may indicate respiratory failure, which can lead to cardiac arrest.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's sinus tachycardia may indicate cardiac arrhythmias, which can lead to cardiac arrest.
7. Anemia: The patient's decrease in Hct from 32 to 26 overnight may indicate anemia, which can lead to cardiac complications.
8. DVT: The patient's prophylaxis for DVT may indicate a risk of DVT, which can lead to pulmonary embolism.
9. VAP: The patient's prophylaxis for VAP may indicate a risk of VAP, which can lead to respiratory failure.
10. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glycemic control may indicate a risk of hypoglycemia, which can lead to cardiac complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal cancer, and recent left pleural effusion and pericardial effusion. He was admitted to the hospital with asymptomatic tachycardia and is now being transferred to the CCU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade. The patient underwent pericardiocentesis with drainage of 250cc serous fluid and placement of a pericardial drain. A post-procedure ECHO showed nearly resolved effusion, and the patient remains hemodynamically stable. The plan is for a pericardial window by thoracic surgery today.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Recurrent pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion is recurrent, which may lead to further tamponade and cardiac compromise.
2. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's pericardial effusion is causing cardiac tamponade, which can lead to cardiac arrest and death if not managed promptly.
3. Hypovolemia: The patient's hypovolemic status may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to further cardiac compromise and potential cardiac arrest.
4. Respiratory compromise: The patient's pleural effusion may lead to respiratory compromise if not managed promptly.
5. Infection: The patient's pericardial drain may become infected, leading to sepsis and potential cardiac compromise.
6. Malignant effusions: The patient's esophageal cancer may lead to malignant pleural and pericardial effusions, which can be challenging to manage and may lead to poor outcomes.
7. Anemia: The patient's microcytic anemia may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to further cardiac compromise and potential cardiac arrest.
8. Hypoglycemia: The patient's history of elevated fasting blood sugars and potential diabetes may lead to hypoglycemia if not managed effectively.
9. DVT: The patient's immobility and history of cancer may increase the risk of DVT, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and potential death.
10. Pain management: The patient's pain management plan may need to be adjusted to ensure adequate pain control and prevent potential complications such as respiratory compromise and hypovolemia.

The patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal cancer, and recent left pleural effusion and pericardial effusion. He was admitted to the ICU with asymptomatic tachycardia and is now being transferred to the CCU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade. He underwent pericardiocentesis, which drained 250cc of serous fluid, and a pericardial drain was placed. The patient has continued to drain 130cc of serous fluid since the procedure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 109bpm, blood pressure of 110/71mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. He is tachypneic with shallow breathing and has decreased breath sounds at the bases. His abdomen is soft and non-tender, and his extremities are warm and well-perfused.

Laboratory results show a hemoglobin of 26.0g/dL, hematocrit of 29.0%, and platelet count of 158 K/uL. His white blood cell count is 14.9 K/uL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 27.2mg/dL.

The patient has a tentative plan for a pericardial window procedure today and will have further plans for his esophageal cancer and malignant pleural and pericardial effusions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pericardial tamponade: The patient's recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade may lead to cardiac tamponade, which can cause cardiac arrest and death.
2. Malignant pleural and pericardial effusions: The patient's esophageal cancer may spread to his pleura and pericardium, leading to malignant effusions that can cause respiratory and cardiac compromise.
3. Hypovolemia: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may indicate hypovolemia, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
4. Respiratory compromise: The patient's tachypnea and decreased breath sounds at the bases may indicate respiratory compromise, which can lead to respiratory failure and death.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications during the pericardial window procedure.
6. Infection: The patient's pericardial drain and surgical site may be at risk for infection, which can lead to sepsis and death.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of hypertension and dyslipidemia may increase his risk for cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction and cardiac arrhythmias.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal cancer, and recent left pleural effusion and pericardial effusion.
* He was admitted to the hospital with asymptomatic tachycardia and is now being transferred to the CCU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade.
* The patient has a pericardial drain in place, which has drained 130cc of serous fluid since the procedure.
* He remains hemodynamically stable, but is at risk for further complications due to the pericardial effusion and tamponade.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Recurrent pericardial effusion and tamponade: The patient's pericardial effusion is not fully resolved, and there is a risk of further accumulation of fluid, which could lead to cardiac tamponade and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Malignant pleural and pericardial effusions: The patient's esophageal cancer may have spread to the pleura and pericardium, leading to malignant effusions that could cause respiratory and cardiac compromise.
* Hypovolemia: The patient's tachycardia and decreased blood pressure suggest that he may be hypovolemic, which could lead to further complications such as decreased cardiac output and organ dysfunction.
* Respiratory compromise: The patient's decreased breath sounds at the bases and shallow breathing may indicate respiratory compromise, which could worsen if not addressed.
* Infection: The patient's pericardial drain and surgical site may be at risk for infection, which could lead to sepsis and other complications.
* Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and recent surgery may increase his risk of bleeding, which could lead to further complications.

**Plan:**

* The patient will undergo a pericardial window procedure today to drain the pericardial effusion and potentially alleviate tamponade.
* The patient's pleural effusion will be drained during the procedure as well.
* The patient will continue to be monitored closely for signs of cardiac tamponade, respiratory compromise, and other complications.
* The patient's fluid status will be closely monitored, and further fluid boluses will be given as needed to maintain adequate blood pressure.
* The patient's respiratory status will be closely monitored, and further respiratory support will be given as needed to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
* The patient's surgical site will be closely monitored for signs of infection, and further antibiotic coverage will be given as needed to prevent infection.

Based on the patient's 24-hour events and progress note, the following summary is provided:

The patient underwent pericardiocentesis, yielding 250cc of serous fluid, and a drain was placed. A repeat echocardiogram showed the drain in place. A plan for a pericardial window procedure by thoracic surgery is scheduled for tomorrow. The patient's Hct dropped from 32 to 26, which was later rechecked and found to be 29.

The patient's surgical site on the right upper back was noted to be slightly dehisced, and thoracic surgery was notified. A swab was sent for culture. The patient continued to be tachycardic, with a heart rate in the teens, and received another 500ml bolus and was started on maintenance fluids.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Tmax: 37.6°C (99.7°F)
* Tcurrent: 37.3°C (99.1°F)
* HR: 109 (98-122) bpm
* BP: 110/71 (80) mmHg
* RR: 20 (11-29) inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 97%

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 14.9, 12.3, 8.0
* Hct: 26.0, 29.0, 27.2
* Plt: 154, 166, 158
* Cr: 0.7, 0.6
* TropT: <0.01
* Glucose: 151, 119

The patient's diagnosis includes wound dehiscence, pericardial effusion without tamponade, pleural effusion, acute ineffective coping, and pain control (acute and chronic).

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis from the dehisced surgical site
* Cardiac tamponade if the pericardial effusion is not managed properly
* Respiratory compromise due to the pleural effusion
* Wound infection or dehiscence
* Fluid overload from the maintenance fluids
* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to the patient's glucose levels
* Thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy due to the patient's platelet count and INR
* Respiratory failure or ARDS due to the patient's respiratory status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour post-pericardiocentesis with a drain in place. The patient has a significant drop in hematocrit from 32 to 26, which was rechecked and found to be 29. The surgical site on the right upper back is slightly dehisced, and a swab was sent for culture.

The patient continues to be tachycardic with a heart rate in the teens, and another 500ml bolus was given. The patient was started on maintenance fluids overnight.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C (99.7°F), heart rate of 109 bpm, blood pressure of 110/71 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 97%.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a tachycardic, regular rhythm with distant heart sounds, and a soft pericardial rub. The patient has decreased breath sounds at the bases (left greater than right) without crackles, wheezes, or rhonchi.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.9, hemoglobin of 8.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 154. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Infection: The patient has a slightly dehisced surgical site, which increases the risk of infection. The swab sent for culture may help identify the causative organism.
2. Pericardial tamponade: Although the patient's pericardial effusion is not causing tamponade, there is still a risk of tamponade developing if the effusion increases in size.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's decreased breath sounds at the bases and tachypnea may indicate early signs of respiratory failure.
4. Sepsis: The patient's tachycardia, tachypnea, and decreased breath sounds may be indicative of sepsis.
5. Bleeding: The patient's low platelet count and decreased hematocrit may increase the risk of bleeding.

Given the patient's condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of the pericardial drain, as well as the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status. The patient's pain control and nutritional needs should also be carefully managed.

Summary:

The patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal cancer, and recent pericardial effusion with tamponade. He was admitted to the ICU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade. The patient underwent pericardiocentesis and a pericardial window via video-assisted thoracotomy. He remains hemodynamically stable with a heart rate of 91 bpm and a blood pressure of 99/55 mmHg.

The patient has a chest tube in place, which has drained 400 mL of serosanguinous fluid. His respiratory status is stable, and he is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula. His blood glucose levels are stable, and he is being monitored for signs of sepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a history of recurrent pericardial effusion, which can lead to cardiac tamponade and cardiac arrest. Monitoring the patient's cardiac status and pericardial fluid levels is crucial.
2. Pleural effusions: The patient has bilateral pleural effusions, which can cause respiratory distress and compromise lung function. Monitoring the patient's respiratory status and pleural fluid levels is essential.
3. Microcytic anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level has decreased overnight, which can lead to anemia and fatigue. Monitoring the patient's hemoglobin levels and treating anemia with iron supplements is necessary.
4. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension, which can increase the risk of cardiac complications. Monitoring the patient's blood pressure and adjusting medications as necessary is crucial.
5. Sepsis: The patient has a history of recent surgery and pericardiocentesis, which can increase the risk of sepsis. Monitoring the patient's vital signs, blood cultures, and lab results is essential to detect early signs of sepsis.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of sinus tachycardia, which can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias. Monitoring the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjusting medications as necessary is crucial.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including pericardial effusion, pleural effusions, microcytic anemia, hypertension, sepsis, and cardiac arrhythmias. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, lab results, and treatment plan is necessary to prevent and manage these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and locally-advanced esophageal cancer who underwent chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and esophagectomy. He was admitted to the hospital with asymptomatic tachycardia and is now being transferred to the CCU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade. The patient underwent pericardiocentesis and a pericardial window procedure, but the pericardium remains scarred and unclear if the window is complete. He also has bilateral pleural effusions, and a left chest tube has been placed.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 91 bpm, blood pressure of 99/55 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His respiratory status remains stable, and he is being monitored closely for possible re-accumulation of pericardial fluid.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pericardial effusion re-accumulation: The patient's pericardium remains scarred, and it is unclear if the pericardial window is complete, which may lead to re-accumulation of pericardial fluid.
2. Tamponade: The patient's early tamponade may worsen if the pericardial fluid re-accumulates, leading to cardiac tamponade and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Pulmonary complications: The patient's bilateral pleural effusions may lead to respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure, if not managed properly.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level has decreased overnight, which may be due to dilutional anemia secondary to fluid resuscitation.
5. Infection: The patient's surgical wounds and lines may be at risk for infection, which could lead to sepsis and other complications.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is uncertain, and his sinus tachycardia may worsen if not managed properly.
7. Malignant effusions: The patient's esophageal cancer may spread to his pericardium and pleura, leading to malignant effusions and potentially life-threatening complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and locally-advanced esophageal cancer who underwent chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and esophagectomy. He was admitted to the hospital with asymptomatic tachycardia and is now being transferred to the cardiac care unit (CCU) with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade. The patient has undergone pericardiocentesis and pericardial window creation via video-assisted thoracotomy.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C (97°F), heart rate of 91 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 99/55 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on nasal cannula.

The patient has bilateral pleural effusions and retrocardiac opacity, which are largely unchanged. A left chest tube was placed intra-operatively and has drained 400 mL of serosanguinous fluid. The patient's cardiac rhythm is sinus tachycardia, which has improved with fluid boluses.

The patient has a microcytic anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 23.6 g/dL, which has decreased from a baseline of 23-27 g/dL. His platelet count is 151 K/uL, and his white blood cell count is 14.9 K/uL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pericardial tamponade: The patient's recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade may lead to cardiac compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Pleural effusions: The patient's bilateral pleural effusions may continue to accumulate and cause respiratory compromise.
3. Anemia: The patient's microcytic anemia may worsen and lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cardiac output.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure may continue to be unstable, potentially leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
5. Infection: The patient's pericardial window and thoracic surgery may increase his risk of infection, particularly pneumonia and sepsis.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's sinus tachycardia may persist or worsen, potentially leading to cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's immobility and surgical procedures may increase his risk of pulmonary embolism, which could be life-threatening.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to monitor his vital signs closely and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent and manage potential complications.

The patient's chest tube was placed, and the CXR showed a left chest tube traversing the left apex to terminate in the mid-left hemithorax, with no pneumothorax. The patient had bilateral pleural effusions and retrocardiac opacity, which remained largely unchanged.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C (97°F), heart rate of 91 bpm, blood pressure of 99/55 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 7.5 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 23.5%
* Platelet count: 151 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 14.9 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 12 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Glucose: 151 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General: Well-appearing patient in mild-moderate discomfort
* Neck: No elevation of jugular venous pressure
* Cardiac: Tachycardic, S1/S2 present
* Lungs: Decreased breath sounds at bases (left > right), without crackles, wheezes, or rhonchi
* Abdomen: Normal abdominal sounds, soft, non-tender, non-distended
* Extremities: Warm and well-perfused, 1+ left lower extremity edema
* Skin: Right upper back surgical scar slightly erythematous with a small dehisced area that is packed with a wick and covered with a dry dressing

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

1. Infection: The patient's surgical site is at risk for infection, and the presence of a chest tube and bilateral pleural effusions increases the risk of respiratory and cardiac complications.
2. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly at the surgical site.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's decreased breath sounds and bilateral pleural effusions may indicate respiratory compromise, which could lead to respiratory failure.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and scarred pericardium may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac tamponade.
5. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance is positive, which may increase the risk of fluid overload and cardiac complications.

Based on this information, it is recommended that the patient be closely monitored for signs of infection, bleeding, respiratory failure, cardiac complications, and fluid overload, and that aggressive management of these potential complications be initiated promptly if they arise.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient underwent a pericardial window procedure, which revealed scarred pericardium, and a porta cath was removed. A chest tube was placed, and a CXR showed left chest tube traversing the left apex to terminate in the mid-left hemithorax. The patient has bilateral pleural effusions and retrocardiac opacity, which has remained largely unchanged.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a Tmax of 37.2°C, Tcurrent of 36.1°C, HR of 91 bpm, BP of 99/55 mmHg, RR of 14 breaths per minute, and SpO2 of 100%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.

Laboratory results show:

* Hct: 26.8%
* WBC: 14.9
* Plt: 151 K/uL
* Cr: 0.7 mg/dL
* TropT: <0.01
* Glucose: 151 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 14.3/28.6/1.2, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 18/<0.01/<0.01, Amylase/Lipase: /21, Differential-Neuts: 90.9%, Lymph: 3.8%, Mono: 5.2%, Eos: 0.2%, LDH: 137 IU/L, Ca++: 7.4 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL, PO4: 3.9 mg/dL

The patient has the following medical conditions:

* Wound dehiscence
* Pericardial effusion (without tamponade)
* Pleural effusion, acute
* Ineffective coping
* Pain control (acute pain, chronic pain)

The patient is receiving ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and lines. Prophylactic measures include DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP prevention.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Cardiac tamponade due to pericardial effusion
* Respiratory failure due to pleural effusion
* Sepsis or infection due to wound dehiscence or other sources
* Hypovolemic shock due to fluid loss or inadequate fluid replacement
* Respiratory acidosis or alkalosis due to changes in respiratory status
* Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia due to inadequate glycemic control
* Thromboembolic events due to DVT prophylaxis failure
* VAP or other nosocomial infections due to inadequate ventilation or hygiene measures.

   Assessment and Plan
   54-yo man with hypertension, dyslipidemia, locally-advanced esophageal
   cancer s/p chemo-XRT & esophagectomy, recent left pleural effusion s/p
   thoracentesis and recent pericardial effusion with tamponade s/p
   pericardiocentesis [**2112-5-23**], who was admitted to [**Hospital1 2266**] with asymptomatic
   tachycardia and is now being transferred to CCU with recurrent
   pericardial effusion and early tamponade.
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Patient is s/p pericardiocentesis [**5-29**] and s/p
   pericardial window via video assisted thoracotomy [**5-30**].  Given
   thickened appearance of pericardium thoracics unclear if window
   complete. Again, we feel etiology of recurrent pericardial fluid
   reaccumulation is recent [**Doctor First Name **] vs XRT. Thickened pericardium would be
   more consistent with XRT.
   -f/u pericardial fluid cxs and cytology from [**5-29**] and [**5-30**]
   -f/u thoracics recs
   -pain control with dilaudid PCA and toradol
   -monitor hemodynamics closely given concern for possible
   re-accumulation if window was not complete
   -recheck an ECHO
   -CXR today
   .
   # Pleural effusions: Left chest tube placed intra-operatively. Has
   drained 400 mL serosanguinous fluid. Resp status remains stable.
   ..
   # Anemia: 3 pt Hct drop overnight. Likely dilutional since he received
   2 liters and Hct previously stable post procedure.
   - active T and S
   - check PM Hct
   - cont oral iron supplements
   - guiac stools
   .
   # CORONARIES - No h/o CAD, normal stress 1/[**2111**].
   .
   # PUMP - TTEs all with EF >55%. Appears euvolemic.
   .
   # RHYTHM - Sinus tachycardia has improved with fluid boluses.
   - cont small fluid boluses as needed
   - cont to monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Esophageal Ca - Pt s/p chemo-XRT and esophagectomy. Concern for
   malignant pleural and pericardial effusions.
   - further plans per primary oncology team, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5112**]
   - f/u thoracic surgery recs, appreciate involvement
   .
   # Hypertension
 BP remains stable.
   - cont to hold atenolol
   .
   # Dyslipidemia - Previously treated with Lovastatin, but has been off
   this since diagnosis of esophageal Ca.
   - lipid panel pending
   .
   #  Diabetes: Blood sugars stable on ISS.
   - FSBS QIDACHS, HISS to cover
   .
   FEN: diabetic// cardiac diet. IVF hydration. Replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: PIVs
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots
   -Pain management with dilaudid PCA and toradol
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, Dulcolax
   FULL CODE
   DISPO: CCU for now

He was admitted to the hospital with asymptomatic tachycardia and is now being transferred to the Cardiac Care Unit (CCU) with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade.

The patient has undergone pericardiocentesis and pericardial window via video-assisted thoracotomy. However, the pericardial window was found to be scarred diffusely, and it is unclear if the window was complete. The patient is at risk for re-accumulation of pericardial fluid, and close monitoring of hemodynamics is necessary.

The patient also has pleural effusions, which were drained intra-operatively. He has a chest tube in place, and his respiratory status remains stable.

The patient's anemia is likely dilutional, given the 2 liters of IV fluids he received overnight. His hemoglobin level has dropped by 3 points, and he is receiving oral iron supplements.

The patient's cardiac status is stable, with a sinus tachycardia that has improved with fluid boluses. He has no history of coronary artery disease and has normal stress tests.

The patient has a history of esophageal cancer, and there is concern for malignant pleural and pericardial effusions. Further plans will be made in consultation with the primary oncology team.

The patient's blood pressure is stable, and he is not receiving atenolol. His lipid panel is pending.

The patient's diabetes is well-controlled, and he is receiving insulin sliding scale therapy. He is also receiving a cardiac diet and IV fluids.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Re-accumulation of pericardial fluid, which can lead to cardiac tamponade and compromise cardiac function.
2. Pneumonia, which can occur due to the patient's compromised respiratory status and the presence of a chest tube.
3. Sepsis, which can occur due to the patient's compromised immune system and the presence of a chest tube.
4. Anemia, which can worsen the patient's overall condition and increase the risk of complications.
5. Hypertension, which can worsen the patient's cardiac status and increase the risk of complications.
6. Malignant pleural and pericardial effusions, which can worsen the patient's overall condition and increase the risk of complications.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and locally-advanced esophageal cancer, who underwent chemo-XRT and esophagectomy. He was admitted to the ICU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade, which was treated with pericardiocentesis and a pericardial window via video-assisted thoracotomy. The patient has also developed a pleural effusion and a surgical wound infection.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pericardial effusion re-accumulation:** The patient's pericardial window may not be complete, which could lead to re-accumulation of fluid and tamponade.
2. **Pleural effusion re-accumulation:** The patient's pleural effusion may re-accumulate, requiring further drainage and treatment.
3. **Surgical wound infection:** The patient's surgical wound is infected with pan-sensitive staph, which could lead to further complications if not properly treated.
4. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia may worsen if he continues to bleed or if his hemoglobin levels drop further.
5. **Hypertension:** The patient's hypertension may worsen if not properly controlled, which could lead to further complications such as cardiac disease.
6. **Dyslipidemia:** The patient's dyslipidemia may worsen if not properly treated, which could lead to further complications such as cardiovascular disease.
7. **Diabetes:** The patient's diabetes may worsen if not properly controlled, which could lead to further complications such as ketoacidosis or hyperglycemia.
8. **Pneumonia:** The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is at risk for developing pneumonia due to his pleural effusion and surgical wound.
9. **Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT):** The patient is at risk for developing DVT due to his immobility and medical condition.
10. **Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP):** The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to his prolonged mechanical ventilation.

**Recommendations:**

1. Monitor the patient's pericardial and pleural effusions closely for signs of re-accumulation.
2. Continue to treat the patient's surgical wound infection with antibiotics and dressing changes.
3. Monitor the patient's anemia and hemoglobin levels closely, and consider transfusing blood products if necessary.
4. Continue to control the patient's hypertension and dyslipidemia with medication and lifestyle changes.
5. Monitor the patient's diabetes and adjust his insulin regimen as necessary.
6. Consider prophylactic antibiotics to prevent DVT and VAP.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as necessary.
8. Consider referring the patient to a cardiologist for further management of his cardiac condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and locally-advanced esophageal cancer who underwent chemo-XRT and esophagectomy. He was admitted to the ICU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade. The patient underwent pericardiocentesis on [**5-29**] and a pericardial window via video-assisted thoracotomy on [**5-30**]. The pericardial effusion is stable, but the etiology of the recurrent effusion is unclear. The patient has a chest tube in place for a left pleural effusion, which has drained 100 mL of serosanguinous fluid since midnight. The patient's hemodynamics are stable, and he is receiving IV fluids and antibiotics for a surgical wound that is draining.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Recurrent pericardial effusion and tamponade: The patient's pericardial effusion is stable, but there is a risk of recurrence if the pericardial window is not complete.
2. Infection: The patient's surgical wound is draining and has a positive culture for pan-sensitive staph. There is a risk of infection spreading to other areas of the body.
3. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 22.5 g/dL, which is low. There is a risk of anemia worsening if the patient's bleeding is not controlled.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient has a left pleural effusion, which may cause respiratory distress. There is a risk of respiratory failure if the effusion is not managed properly.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of sinus tachycardia, which may worsen if his fluid status is not monitored closely.
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is stable, but there is a risk of hypertension worsening if his fluid status is not monitored closely.
7. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient has a history of diabetes and is receiving insulin therapy. There is a risk of diabetic ketoacidosis if the patient's blood sugar levels are not monitored closely.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and tamponade.
2. Continue to manage the patient's surgical wound and drain it as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamics and adjust his fluid therapy as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and manage his pleural effusion as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac arrhythmias and adjust his medication as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's blood sugar levels and adjust his insulin therapy as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust his transfusion therapy as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and locally-advanced esophageal cancer, who underwent chemo-XRT and esophagectomy. He was admitted to the hospital with asymptomatic tachycardia and is now being transferred to the CCU with recurrent pericardial effusion and early tamponade.

The patient has undergone pericardiocentesis and a pericardial window via video-assisted thoracotomy. The pericardial fluid showed rare atypical cells in a background of reactive cells. The patient's hemodynamics remain stable, but there is concern for possible re-accumulation of pericardial fluid if the window was not complete.

The patient also has a left pleural effusion, which has been drained with a chest tube. His anemia has improved, and he is receiving oral iron supplements. His coronary arteries are normal, and his cardiac function is normal. He has a history of sinus tachycardia, which has improved with fluid boluses.

The patient's medications include:

* Bactrim for growing pan-sensitive staph from his wound
* Toradol for pain control
* Atenolol for hypertension (held)
* Lovastatin for dyslipidemia (discontinued since diagnosis of esophageal cancer)
* FEN (diabetic/cardiac diet) for nutrition
* IVF hydration for fluid management
* Lytes PRN for electrolyte management
* Prophylaxis for DVT and bowel regimen

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Re-accumulation of pericardial fluid if the window was not complete
* Malignant pleural and pericardial effusions due to esophageal cancer
* Hypertension
* Dyslipidemia
* Anemia
* Infection from the wound or chest tube
* Respiratory failure due to pleural effusion
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to sinus tachycardia

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring of hemodynamics and fluid status
* Further evaluation and management of pericardial effusion and pleural effusion
* Management of anemia and electrolyte imbalance
* Pain control with Toradol
* Prophylaxis for DVT and bowel regimen
* Monitoring of blood sugar levels and adjustment of insulin as needed
* Further plans per primary oncology team for esophageal cancer management.
